algorithms.shortestPaths

Class BellmanFord

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.shortestPaths.BellmanFord

  • public class BellmanFord
extends java.lang.Object
    solves the single source paths problem. It can handle negative edge weights, but if there is a negative cycle, it returns false. It solves the problem using dynamic programming (= dividing the problem into sub-problems and combining them into the solution). It is non-greedy solution that uses the relax function to find the minimum edge for a node. relax is invoked |V| - 1 times. Runtime complexity is O(|V||E|). implemented following Cormen et al. "Introduction to Algorithms"
    Author:
    nichole

    • Constructor Detail

      • BellmanFord

        public BellmanFord(SimpleLinkedListNode[] dAG,
                   gnu.trove.map.TIntIntMap[] weights,
                   int sourceVertex)
        Parameters:
        dAG - directed acyclic graph where the main index of the object array is the vertex number, and each vertex has a linked list of outgoing edges connecting to the vertexes held in each linked list node key. Note that all vertexes, including edge vertexes, must be present as an index of the array dAG, i.e. all vertexes must have numerical value less than dAG.length.
        weights - the edge weights in format of outer array index being the first vertex and the map within having a key being the 2nd vertex of the edge with value being the edge weight.
        sourceVertex - the source vertex index

    • Method Detail

      • find

        public boolean find()
        find the single shortest paths in dAG with edge weights w starting from s.
        Returns:
        returns false if a negative cycle is present, else returns true and the results are usable.
